Topic.Title: Why NVIDIA's Shield will succeed, part I

Message.Msg: "There is an excellent video made by a prominent gaming software group (I will post the "link" later) in which they say $500 would be a fair price for them, judging from the quality of hardware and features already announced. I personally don't think Shield will be marketed under $350 at launch." Ibexx Since the BOM and Mfg cost cannot be more than $150, I believe the sweet spot for the gamer market and semi serious casual gamer market is $299 with occassional coupon sale of X off with very high end Geforce discrete cards at Newegg, Tigerdirect etc. Nick Stam technical marketing director with Nvidia said in a Video that Nvidia would have the device in e-tail and retail at launch. The perfect retail store at launch is GameStop with How many stores does GameStop operate, under what names? GameStop has 6,614 stores in operation, of which 4,434 are located in the United States, 343 in Canada, 413 in Australia/New Zealand and 1,424 are in Europe. Our stores operate primarily under the names of GameStop and EB Games. Our stores sell new and used video game software, hardware and accessories for video game systems from Sony, Nintendo, and Microsoft. In addition, the company sells PC entertainment software, related accessories and other merchandise. Talk about instant marketing to your target market. In addition, GameStop's selling of used games and equipment ties extremely well Nvidia's professed desire to do what helps the Gamer! Note: GameStop even sells used IPads and the sales people actually know what they are talking about...not like BestBuy...LOL JMHO

Message.Title: "Has NVIDIA Made A Huge Mistake?"
Message.Msg: "I think the only chance of Shield succeeding is if it's incredibly cheap. Many low-end Android phones are free with a data plan, and the fact that these phones do almost everything that Shield does and more makes Shield a very tough sell. I've written about NVIDIA and think the stock is extremely cheap, but this gives me a little pause. My guess is that NVIDIA will try to sell Shield for at least a few hundred dollars, comparable to the price of the PS Vita and more expensive than any smart phone purchased with a plan. At that price point I don't see a clear market for this thing. What's worse, traditionally makers of game systems sell the system at a loss and then recoup the cost from game licensing fees. This allows the system cost to be fairly low. This is not possible with the Shield. Hopefully, NVIDIA built Project Shield to simply showcase the power of the Tegra 4 processor and doesn't expect it to go mainstream. Otherwise, I think this is a pretty serious misstep." foolDOTcom

Topic.Title: "Nvidia is Doomed!"

Message.Msg: "But Nvidia still appears to be focussed on premium gaming. Its Tegra 4 processors have 72 GPU cores, which are believed to be better than Snapdragon’s Adreno 330, developed by AMD. Gauging by its expected expensive price tag, I believe it would attract gamers with deep pockets. In my opinion, NVidia is limiting its market share. A faster Snapdragon 800 may perform the task of a mobile desktop, but a Tegra 4 device would perform the job of a handheld gaming device. Doesn’t make much sense to me!" source: foolDOTcom

Topic.Title: Why NVIDIA's Shield will succeed, part I

Message.Msg: GameStop has a huge market in used games, consols, tablets, and yes even IPads in my locale. Quite knowledgeable clerks too. It's kinda of ironic that apparently they take a much smaller slice from the mfg. to sell new gamer merchandize, and make most of their profit on selling used equipment and games. BestBuy and other mainstream retailers take a much larger slice on new stuff and are terrible in product knowledge from my experience. I think it would be a waste of time for Nvidia to hook up with them unless they got a very very good deal or it was a special XMAS promotion because the Shield had become such a huge hit with the mainstream which I doubt. It's a gamer add-on this year and I suspect it will be extremely popular with gamers this year...but mainstream not this year. After all the CEO of Nvidia said the Shield is not a product for 6 year olds or grandmothers and our target market is gamers. Even with that said, it will not surpirse me if the Shield sells 1M to 2M units in it's first year and bring along additional sales of high end Geforce cards. All highly profitable! With all the free advertising that has happened and will continue as Nvidia Grid comes into play later this year, I cannot image it not be accretive to earnings immediately. Best words I heard at CES was "We will make money on each and every unit we sell."

Working capital earns 30 to 50%... why is this money in cash and not being used as working capital? What are they waiting for? our next life! 4 years go by...that is 10-15% of our economic life....

Message.Title: Yoshida in Vegas: Chasing elusive LTE design wins
Message.Msg: Yoshida in Vegas: Chasing elusive LTE design wins Junko Yoshida 1/16/2013 1:12 PM EST LAS VEGAS – A number of reputable chip companies, including ST-Ericsson, Renesas Mobile, NVidia, Marvell, have been developing LTE baseband chips for more than a year. So far, there is little to show for it. All claim they already have their modem chips on the tarmac. But that’s it. No takeoff. Nothing about actual design wins. CES last week was no exception. We heard zilch. How come? We can certainly blame the virtually non-existent LTE market for that. Except in the U.S., the roll out of LTE has been slow. If you want volume for your modem chips, you need to play not in LTE but the 3G market dominated by Qualcomm, MediaTek, Spreadtrum, Broadcom, Intel and others. Additional blame goes to Samsung and Apple. The two companies have pretty much sewn up the high-end smartphone market. Samsung designs its own LTE baseband chips while Apple uses Qualcomm’s chips. Not much room is left for anyone else. But the real story lies in the very nature of a baseband chip, which we in the media apparently don’t appreciate very much. Developing a functional baseband chip is a never-ending job, according to CEVA CEO Gideon Wertheizer. When it comes to apps processors, chip suppliers know their job is done. It happens when they see tape out. In contrast, baseband chips, after tape-out, need to be tweaked, tested, modified, certified and/or tweaked again before they can move to mass production. Wertheizer said, “I’ve heard that you’d need to dispatch something like 400 engineers to Samsung in order to have your chip tested in their handsets, certified by different operators and tweaked to work well on different bands, and finally getting designed in.” Come on. Four hundred? Really?

Topic.Title: I'm long, but sekking alpa blogger is alwys wrong

Message.Msg: The chart is very bad here, all the long term averages are above the short term ones and the stock price is below all of them i.e. multiple death crosses. stockchartsDOTcom/c-sc/sc?s=nvda&p=D&yr=1&mn=0&dy=0&i=t77909490371&r=1358345946442 How did this come about ? Well the stock got pumped up to $26 on tablet/phone growth fever and when the results didn't come the stock crashed leaving the overhanging medium/long term averages above you as resistance. It does not help that there is habitual bad PC news which has tended to kill any spikes you have had. You really need Tegra to turn a corner and to start breaking even at least before the market views you as anything other than Intel's companion in legacy PCs. Tegra 4 in tablets and Project Shield will probably get you there. As to your comment about using cash well sometimes it is just viewed as unproductive R&D if you spend too much of it for too long without any noticeable results e.g. Tegra 1/2/3 . It needs to be spent wisely and to be seen to be spent wisely.

In contrast, baseband chips, after tape-out, need to be tweaked, tested, modified, certified and/or tweaked again before they can move to mass production." This is where SDR's have their benefit.

Message.Title: Nvidia 2013- Back To The Future
Message.Msg: It's been a rough couple of years for Nvidia. From the Intel squeeze killing Nvidia chipsets to Qualcomm bundling LTE. Yet Nvidia has managed to accumulate $2B more in cash than they had 2.5 years ago. But there is hope with Nvidia's "Back To The Future Campaign" in 2013 and what's neat is the simplicity of it. "Hey we are not a PC company, We are a GAMING company." Ala Tegra 4 is released and the first product is a gaming device that ties to Nvidia gaming GPUs which is sold to gamers. Imagine the Launch Party at E3 in Boston in early May...500 select guests raffled of course with Nvidia Grid playing multi-player games on 500 Project Shields all night with the top 3 teams taking home a mucho Nvidia Gaming gear as GameStop starts selling Project Shield bundled with 4 new Exclusive Game Tegra 4 for a period of time. Videos to follow on YouTube comparing these games visual effects on the Shield or a Tegra 4 tablet to an IPad of course. Beautiful way to Ring Fence Nvidia's gamer revenue which is substantial and approaching $2.5B a year. And establish the user base for Tegra optimized games in tablets which will only make theGame Developers double down even more. Of course a few high end phones will pick up Tegra 4 at WWM at the end of February and probably I500 modems too, but what else would you expect with QCOM charging so much. Just a start but not part of Nvidia's 2013 Back To The Future Campaign.

Message.Title: NVDA prospects
Message.Msg: Blogging heads are either very gung-ho on NVDA prospects or, its all doom and gloom. I have come to realize that Nvidia as a company doesn't really care about near term stock price. They have a general vision of building the best compute solutions they can. They keep driving on that general vision, making tweaks to their roadmap etc. as they go. Its clear that Nvidia is an engineering driven company - at this time more so than INTC and AMD. I would rate Qualcomm as a much more disciplined mix of engineering and market messaging. Broadcom as a quiet worker and TXN as pragmatic, very well managed company. If you want to sleep well at night, buy TXN and BRCM on dips and forget about it. Qualcomm is fully valued, it can only go down if it has any significant misstep. INTC is headed the wrong way and is to be avoided (can someone explain #$%$ was Macfee buy for?) AMD is a value trap. and Nvidia is a tease - to be flirted with on dips and dumped for small returns... for now. Nvidia has to show some returns on its R&D investments this year or, they will be punished by the market. Nvidia OpEx has been going up too fast, they are still hiring big time in UK (Icera - Bristol, Cambridge and Sophia/France). Multiple tape-outs each Qtr (this is the reason TXN said goodbye to all things digital). GE jingle was - "we bring good things to life". Nvidia may as well come out with a jingle - "we bring things that nobody is asking for to life". Now this is broadly the mantra that Apple "had" - Gretzky philosophy... Except you better be right and on time else you may pull a "Newton". I can hypothesis that Nvidia is getting better on execution as it goes. Hopefully Tegra 4 is in products at MWC. I find Icera viability still questionable and so "Grey" is still not certain. I wonder if there is more to the story behind Project Shield. Nvidia wants to make a serious foray in entertainment products. I think its pretty well known that Valve/Steam Box is based on Nvidia - I wonder if this will be Project Denver. Lots of earnings (and maybe some pre-announcements) next week - good luck all.

Topic.Title: Dualing Websites

Message.Msg: Ashraf, You are a good writer, but you need to branch out because your track record on stock recommends is not exactly stellar. I do realize that the appeal of $4,000 a month from clicks on S/A is appealing, but write some articles about the debt ceiling, Australian bonds, Caterpillar, or the Japanese yen etc. rather than just writing on stocks that have the most followers. It will broaden your appeal and bring you much more credibility than you now possess. And perhaps a salary gig with a financial analyst company. Hard choice I know when expenses and college tuition must be paid. Good Luck!

Message.Title: Thanks a Million, Best.
Message.Msg: Thanks Best! For being the Only poster here to give that very timely Warning about the dangerous, rocky shoals which plummeting PC sales pose to the hapless PC parts makers -- like nvidia. Why, if it wasn't for your singular and very astute and timely Warning to the readers on this board, the shocking news from Mister Paul S. Otellini that PC sales are plummeting might very well have torpedoed, -- yes boys, torpedoed -- the accounts of many readers here. Like it did today to the not-so-astute investors in PC parts maker nvidia. Those that don't read the Words of Best. Thanks a Million, Best.

Topic.Title: ..... BARUUUGA! ..... BARUUUGA! .....

Message.Msg: Agreed Best. Mister ashraf.eassa appears to be just another nvda bagholder, -- badly underwater on his long position -- trying his best to talk the stock back to close to where he overpaid for it. We see it ALL the time here on this board.

Topic.Title: NVDA prospects

Message.Msg: o.investor Some great points here, but I think Nvidia is already pretty punished by the market for the reasons that you mention. By all means, it could continue to be punished further, but I think the more "gung ho" longs (such as myself) believe the investments that the company is making are the right ones.

Topic.Title: Thanks a Million, Best.

Message.Msg: Are you really going to get excited over an $0.08/share drop?

Topic.Title: Dualing Websites

Message.Msg: So as I understand this case, and correct me if I wrong counselors, the defendant claimed on the global Yahoo! Finance Message Board for Nvidia -- that, "I am a hapless Holder of NVDA stock" -- yet at the same time posted on the SeekingAlpha Message Board for Nvidia, and OMITTED the crucial element that he is a hapless NVDA shareholder. Is that correct, counselors? "Yes, your Honor." "Umble mumble mumble" Speak up now, defendant's counselor, and quit mumbling at your feet. Ya-ya-ya yes, your Honor, my client IS guilty. Seeing no other lame defenses, we move to my ruling in this case. Mister ashraf.eassa, I Judge Best sentence you to the B.S. Don't Fly List.

Topic.Title: NVDA prospects

Message.Msg: "Blogging heads are either very gung-ho on NVDA prospects or, its all doom and gloom." Agree... "I have come to realize that Nvidia as a company doesn't really care about near term stock price. They have a general vision of building the best compute solutions they can. They keep driving on that general vision, making tweaks to their roadmap etc. as they go. Its clear that Nvidia is an engineering driven company - " Agree... We can see everything nVidia communincates to everything NVidia... And it's all gonna be centered around PD... "more so than INTC and AMD." Far beyond AMD, but INTC fabs are beyond impressive... "I can hypothesis that Nvidia is getting better on execution as it goes. " How I wish you were right !!! But execution, NVidia's former strong suit, is now their weakest... Everything is late, and a year behind... ""Grey" is still not certain." Grey is certain... just hope we see it before Tegra 5... Prospects: NVidia will live or die with PD & beyond... That includes PD cores in Tegra 6 & beyond... But the rewards will be very high if they get it right...

Topic.Title: Dualing Websites

Message.Msg: So Master? The "B.S. Don't Fly List" -- Is that legal jargon? For ibbey's Ignore List? I thought so.

Topic.Title: NVDA prospects

Message.Msg: A PE of 15 is not punishment - its fair market pricing. Very similar to MRVL, INTC etc. They are not being afforded any premium because they have not delivered material earnings growth. A bullish case may be made based on future returns on R&D investments over the last few years but the results are far from certain. There are still macro issues to consider and strength of partners. Nvidia made a decision 3-4 years ago to invest aggressively in CPB business and build products. They could have taken an approach of licensing IP instead. We can only speculate but I think NVDA stock would have been much higher as they would have licensed to all major mobile IGP solutions. In any case, looking at my crystal ball I can say that NVDA will trade at 20+ PE if they meet numbers and provide positive guidance. I also recognize the potential for Nvidia to go nuts (I mean all time highs) if they start delivering consistently. btw I think they will introduce Shield in $400 - $500 range. They will probably sell in small numbers initially. Which is fine as there is not much content and the device will be attractive to very select audience. By holiday time 2013 there should be quite a bit of attractive content on TegraZone for Shield. They will then drop price to sub $400 and sell a lot more. So don't be disappointed if Shield has tepid start. Handhelds (especially gaming) can be a nightmare with customer abuse and returns, warranty etc. I hope they hire the right folks to manage retail experience. I was very disappointed to read reviews on TegraZone (Android Play). Sounds like their is a lot of customer unhappiness with application stability. Nvidia introduced 3D glasses to much promise and fan-fare but I don't think they sell very well (I heard of 500K to date).

Topic.Title: NVDA prospects

Message.Msg: o.investor Thank you for the post. I would say that's a pretty fair assessment of the situation.

Topic.Title: NVDA prospects

Message.Msg: "Nvidia made a decision 3-4 years ago to invest aggressively in CPB business and build products. They could have taken an approach of licensing IP instead." Trying to make their SOC 100% NVidia IP... "I also recognize the potential for Nvidia to go nuts (I mean all time highs) if they start delivering consistently." That's what keeps the longs... long "Nvidia introduced 3D glasses to much promise and fan-fare but I don't think they sell very well " Nobody wants to wear those glasses... But they do want knobs, buttons & levers...
